newsitem.title: USA: Lehman profits rise in first quarter.
newsitem.headline: Lehman profits rise in first quarter.

text.p: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. Monday reported surprisingly strong first-quarter earnings, boosted by a high volume of mergers and acquisitions and other profitable businesses.

The Wall Street firm's profits rose to $144 million, or $1.16 a share, in the quarter ended in February from $104 million, or 79 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenues grew to almost $4 billion from $3.4 billion.
"They beat everybody's estimate," said analyst Raphael Soifer of Brown Brothers Harriman. Wall Street earnings estimates for Lehman ranged from 93 cents to 98 cents a share.
Lehman attributed its strong performance to gains in high-margin businesses, including mergers and acquisitions, initial public offerings, derivatives, and high-yield and emerging markets activities.

Lehman's pre-tax profit margin widened to 23.7 percent in the first quarter from 19.2 percent in the year-ago period. This compared with 20.9 percent for full-year 1996, before a one-time charge in the fourth quarter.
Lehman's stock rose 75 cents to $31.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
